author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Democrats Unite Behind Voting Rights Bill as It Faces a Senate Roadblock
description: With Republicans set to filibuster, Democrats are focusing on staying unified in the face of defeat. But the path ahead for the legislation is murky at best.
content: WASHINGTON — A push by Democrats to enact the most expansive voting rights legislation in generations is set to collapse in the Senate on Tuesday, when Republicans are expected to use a filibuster to block a measure that President Biden and his allies in Congress have called a vital step to protect democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Adams baselessly insists his rivals are trying to suppress Black people’s votes.
description: Eric Adams took aim at an alliance between two rivals, Andrew Yang and Kathryn Garcia. A third, Maya Wiley, who like Mr. Adams is Black, said that she did not see a problem. “I’m not calling this racism,” she said.
content: In a round of early-morning television appearances Monday, Eric Adams continued to criticize an alliance between two of his rivals as an attempt to prevent the city from electing its second Black mayor.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: ‘There’s So Much Energy’: Rules Fall Away, and New Yorkers Haltingly Return to Life
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 21, 2021.
content: “This has really illuminated the ways in which the digitization of all social life has failed. Being in real space with each other is just what humans do.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Here is how to watch the U.S. track and field trials.
description: NBC will have coverage of the trials this evening.
content: If you only want to watch the marquee races Sunday night, you’re in luck. But if you are a die-hard fan of the jumping and throwing events, you might have to work a little bit harder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: ‘I Needed It’: A Well-Timed Outdoor Theater Opens on Little Island
description: The island’s first performances, by Broadway Inspirational Voices choir, were post-pandemic catharsis for both the singers and the audience.
content: The timing could not have been better.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darryn King
title: ‘Inside No. 9’ Returns With More Cunning Puzzles
description: In an interview, the creators Reece Shearsmith and Steve Pemberton discuss the new season and their love of narrative challenges. “It’s been like writing school for us,” Pemberton said.
content: The BBC anthology series “Inside No. 9” feels like “The Twilight Zone” or “Alfred Hitchcock Presents” if they had been written by Will Shortz or Erno Rubik. Episodes turn out to be deviously constructed puzzles, whose pieces fall into place only at the final moment. Twists give way to bigger twists. Major reveals upend everything that has come before. One genre of story turns out to be disguised as another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: An Orchestra Veteran on Music’s Post-Pandemic Future
description: Mark Volpe, retiring after 23 years in charge of the Boston Symphony, says ensembles must embrace technology and education to survive.
content: Mark Volpe grew up steeped in classical music, the son of a trumpet player in the Minnesota Orchestra. An aspiring clarinetist, he stumbled into a career managing orchestras after failing to win auditions for professional ensembles and enrolling in law school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Burns
title: Will Work for Air-Conditioning
description: Some people are heading back to the office just so they can stop feeling like a hot mess.
content: At first, working from home felt like getting away with something. People rejoiced in taking meetings in sweatpants and squeezing in a load of laundry between calls. Commutes shrank and flexibility expanded. Nobody worried about their lunch being stolen from the communal fridge anymore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: Doubters. Haters. Trae Young Has Them. He Doesn’t Care.
description: Young, the Atlanta Hawks guard, has embraced the booing, cursing crowds and his opponents’ defensive pressure. What he hasn’t embraced? Low expectations.
content: Nate McMillan, more than most, knows the unpredictable nature of a point guard equipped with unflinching confidence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Our Southeast Asia bureau chief breaks down the region’s pandemic reality.
content: The countries of Southeast Asia largely escaped the worst of the coronavirus pandemic during its first year. But now, as more infectious variants take hold, the region is suffering from new outbreaks and lockdowns and lags the rest of the world in vaccinations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Landau
title: How Glowing Bacteria in the Dirt May One Day Save Lives
description: Researchers in Israel have recently detailed progress in developing sensors that light up in the presence of a chemical linked to land mines and other deadly explosives.
content: Land mines left over from bygone conflicts — or those still being fought — pose silent threats to millions of people around the world. With the help of bacteria that glow in their presence, these hidden hazards may one day be found and safely removed or destroyed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Kyle Schwarber’s Huge Day Pushes Nationals Past Mets
description: Washington’s slugger homered three times, bringing his two-day total to five. “To be honest with you, I don’t know what’s going on,” Schwarber said.
content: WASHINGTON — Kyle Schwarber homered three times and tied a major league record with five in a two-game span, leading the Washington Nationals over the Mets, 5-2, Sunday to take three of four in the series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: Karl Wirsum, Dynamic and Eclectic Chicago Artist, Dies at 81
description: A member of the small but influential group known as the Hairy Who, he built his art on a highly original synthesis of multiple sources.
content: Karl Wirsum, whose avid, sometimes robotic figures in both two and three dimensions exemplified the group of disruptive artists known in the late 1960s as the Hairy Who, died on May 6 in Chicago. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Why We May Not Know Who Won the Mayoral Primary for Weeks
description: Although the primary is being held on Tuesday, an official winner is unlikely to be named before the week of July 12.
content: The New York City primary election is this Tuesday, but it could be weeks before we find out who won the top contest — the Democratic primary for mayor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips
title: As Lumber Prices Fall, the Threat of Inflation Loses Its Bite
description: Costs soared partly because of do-it-yourselfers’ spending stimulus checks, but a month of declines show that consumers aren’t about to trigger runaway increases.
content: From sawmills to store shelves to your own hammer swings, lumber can tell you a lot about what’s going on in the economy right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura M. Holson
title: I’ve Recovered From Long Covid. I’m One of the Lucky Ones.
description: Much of the country is moving past the pandemic. But many people still can’t, and I know exactly how that feels.
content: I met a friend for lunch recently, one of my first New York social outings since Covid-19 forced the world into solitude 15 months ago. We laughed and shared a bottle of prosecco. We didn’t wear masks. We hugged. Twice. As we offered each other hearty goodbyes after our three-hour gabfest, a woman remarked as she passed us on the street, “It is so good to see people happy again.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Why Did We Fall for the Angels?
description: How the pomp and pageantry of Victoria’s Secret worked for so long.
content: Ever since the news broke that Victoria’s Secret, the lingerie behemoth and Barnum & Bailey of fashion shows, was retiring its bevy of “Angels” in favor of a diverse posse of women with equally diverse resumes, media has been full of gleeful “it’s about time” responses, as well as photos of then and now, taking us down a memory lane of cleavage, costume and sex kitten cliché.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Lance Booth
title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Airlines struggle to cope as travel picks up and storms force delays.
description: Nearly 10,000 flights were delayed on Sunday, the busiest day for U.S. airports since the pandemic arrived.
content: Summer getaways are testing the limits of the country’s air travel system as airlines and airports try to restore operations that were decimated by the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Belarus Faces Expanded E.U. and U.S. Sanctions, Targeting Economy
description: In a new effort to punish the Lukashenko government for repression, Western countries jointly focused on industries crucial to the country, including potash and finance.
content: BRUSSELS — Responding to the detention last month of a young opposition journalist, the United States, the European Union, Britain and Canada joined forces Monday to impose further sanctions on the government of President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus for its abuses of human rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Says Over 200 Patent Judges Were Improperly Appointed
description: A fractured coalition of justices limited the effect of the decision, saying a larger role for an executive branch official would address the matter.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that more than 200 administrative judges who hear patent disputes, some of them over billions of dollars, had been appointed in violation of the Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery
title: Smithfield Foods is sued by an advocacy group claiming it stoked fears of meat shortages.
description: The group claims there were ample supplies of meat in cold storage even as Smithfield warned that the country was in danger of running out of meat.
content: Smithfield Foods was one of the first companies to warn that the country was in danger of running out of meat as coronavirus infections ripped through processing plants in April 2020 and health officials pressured the industry to halt some production to protect workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Armenia’s Governing Party Wins Election Seen as Vote on Peace Deal
description: The party of Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan won a snap parliamentary election in which rivals had talked of renegotiating his unpopular settlement with Azerbaijan.
content: MOSCOW — The party of Armenia’s prime minister, Nikol Pashinyan, won a snap election over the weekend that also signaled at least grudging acceptance by Armenians of a peace settlement negotiated last fall with Azerbaijan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: The Future of New York City
description: We have a primer for tomorrow’s mayoral primaries.
content: New York City voters will head to the polls tomorrow to pick the Democratic and Republican candidates for mayor. The Democratic contest is, essentially, the mayoral election — in a deep blue city like New York, the Democrat will probably win in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Paul Brammer
title: Brandon Taylor’s ‘Filthy Animals’ Is a Study in Rogue Appetites
description: The first story collection from the author of “Real Life” features unspoken desires bubbling up when least appropriate.
content: FILTHY ANIMALS Stories By Brandon Taylor
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Yang makes a final lap of the city, undeterred by a van with broken A.C.
description: Andrew Yang and his campaign vehicle dubbed the Yangatron are leaving no borough unvisited today in his search for votes.
content: Not even 10 minutes into Andrew Yang’s inaugural trip in his campaign van Monday morning and there was a problem. The air conditioning had given out, so the vehicle sporting Mr. Yang’s grinning face on its side had pulled over next to a gas station on Staten Island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Bortz
title: This Season’s Wedding Crashers: Cicadas
description: The insects, which surface every 17 years, have invaded outdoor weddings in several states and the District of Columbia. They’re expected to be gone by early July.
content: The bride and groom were in the middle of exchanging vows when something landed on David Levi’s head. “I particularly don’t like flying bugs, so you could imagine my reaction when a cicada landed on my head and started moving its tiny legs on my scalp,” said Mr. Levi of Bristol, Conn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: Here’s how the candidates are spending the last full day on the campaign trail.
description: The most crowded field of Democratic candidates running for New York City mayor in recent memory makes a collective sprint to the finish line today, crisscrossing the city in dozens of appearances on the last day before Tuesday’s primary. Beware as you leave the house or turn on the TV or radio: You are liable to encounter someone asking for your vote.
content: The most crowded field of Democratic candidates running for New York City mayor in recent memory makes a collective sprint to the finish line today, crisscrossing the city in dozens of appearances on the last day before Tuesday’s primary. Beware as you leave the house or turn on the TV or radio: You are liable to encounter someone asking for your vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Make Melissa Clark’s grilled za’atar chicken with garlic yogurt and cilantro whether or not you have a grill.
content: Good morning. It’s the summer solstice, so you may eat dinner at twilight even if you’re late to get into the kitchen because Mondays are a bear. Let’s make the most of it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Lordstown Motors Opens Up Its Electric Truck Factory to Show Progress
description: After an executive shake-up and conflicting statements about its prospects, the start-up demonstrated prototypes of its pickup.
content: LORDSTOWN, Ohio — Lordstown Motors, a troubled electric-vehicle start-up, began a push to win back the confidence of investors on Monday by demonstrating the abilities of four working prototypes at its Ohio factory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin and Amy Chang Chien
title: Artwork Ranking Women by Their Looks Sets Off a Furor in a Changing China
description: Critics called the piece, which shows thousands of unsuspecting college students, a misogynistic affront, eight years after it was on display in a different museum to little reaction.
content: To the artist’s critics, it was bad enough that he had secretly filmed thousands of female students on a Chinese university campus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Jon Rahm, With Drama on His Side at Last, Wins the U.S. Open
description: In his first tournament back after testing positive for the coronavirus, the Spaniard, 26, birded the final two holes to overtake Louis Oosthuizen and claim his first major title.
content: SAN DIEGO — A golf ball hit by one of the leaders lodged in the limb of a tree. A shot by another contender settled next to an open case of beer. No one seemed able to keep his footing on the 13th tee, where the surface was as unpredictable as a carnival Tilt-A-Whirl. The reigning champion missed a hole in one by an inch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: ‘We’re going to win New York by hustling,’ Yang says as he starts 5-borough tour.
description: As he hit the campaign trail early on Monday morning, Andrew Yang had a message for the supporters and campaign volunteers helping him greet commuters at the Staten Island ferry terminal.
content: As he hit the campaign trail early on Monday morning, Andrew Yang had a message for the supporters and campaign volunteers helping him greet commuters at the Staten Island ferry terminal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: ‘The Hunchback of Notre Dame’ at 25: ‘The Most R-Rated G You Will Ever See’
description: How did the ratings board overlook songs filled with lust and damnation? “Maybe we bamboozled them with gargoyles,” one filmmaker said.
content: They know exactly what they got away with.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cathy Erway
title: More Than ‘Just Takeout’
description: A new generation of Chinese American chefs is celebrating the inventiveness, resourcefulness and deliciousness of American Chinese food with menus dedicated to the classics.
content: In 1983, Tim Ma’s parents opened Bamboo Garden in Conway, Ark. It was a side hustle — his mother was in graduate school, and his father worked full-time as a medical technician. As owners of the only Chinese restaurant in their small town, the Mas made good money in their first year. But it wasn’t without setbacks. There was the brick hurled into their family’s home, the drunken driver who crashed into the restaurant’s dining room and the eventual arrival of competition, when their talented chef opened his own restaurant across the street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: The Olympics will allow 10,000 spectators.
content: Domestic spectators will be allowed to attend Olympic events in Tokyo this summer, the president of the Games announced on Monday, ending months of speculation that athletes could be deprived of a live audience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Telfar Clemens Is Designing Liberia’s Olympic Uniforms
description: They are something to see. And are yet another way this year’s Games are going to be different.
content: The road to the July Olympics has been fraught, to say the least. Citizens of the host country, Japan, don’t want the event to take place. The stadium seats will be largely empty — at least of visiting fans. And people are still confused by the date (2020, instead of 2021). For one team, nevertheless, the Olympics are turning into something of a fairy tale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Srinivasan
title: Google Is Dominating This Hidden Market With No Rules
description: The absence of stringent regulation has allowed the search giant to dominate the powerful market for online advertising. Here's how to fix it.
content: Last month, Gary Gensler, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, asked Congress to consider the idea of regulating cryptocurrency exchanges the way the federal government has long regulated stock exchanges. While his comments drew fresh attention to the unregulated markets for cryptocurrency, they reminded me of another long unregulated exchange marketplace: the market for digital advertising.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Behind Shell’s strategy to get into green energy.
description: Ben van Beurden, the chief executive of Royal Dutch Shell, has been talking about the need to cut emissions since 2017. In the view of some, though, Shell has dragged its feet.
content: Ben van Beurden, the chief executive of Royal Dutch Shell, has been talking about the need to cut emissions since 2017. In the view of some, though, Shell has dragged its feet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Denmark Advances at Euro 2020, Winning Where Eriksen Fell
description: A 4-1 victory over Russia sent Denmark to the knockout stages, a stunning turn in a tournament that began with the collapse of Denmark’s star, Christian Eriksen.
content: Denmark’s players gathered in a circle on the field at the Parken Stadium in Copenhagen and stared intently at a staff member’s phone. They must have known, by then, that they had qualified for the last 16 of the European Championship, but they wanted to be sure. They wanted to see the score confirmed, officially.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Regional elections in France.
content: In France’s first round of nationwide regional elections, voters voiced support for the center-right party, Les Républicains, over the far-right National Rally party, dashing Marine Le Pen’s hopes of turning the vote into a springboard for the presidential race next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: V.A. Plans to Offer Gender Confirmation Surgeries for Transgender Veterans
description: The secretary of veterans affairs announced the shift in care at a Pride event over the weekend, but the process for changing benefits could take years.
content: WASHINGTON — The Department of Veterans Affairs plans to offer gender confirmation surgery to transgender veterans, Denis McDonough, the secretary of veterans affairs, announced over the weekend at a Pride event in Orlando, Fla., in a major shift in available care for former service members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: It’s Novak Djokovic’s Wimbledon. Don’t Roll Your Eyes.
description: The fiery star’s march toward history could force his detractors into an uncomfortable position: giving him his due.
content: At first glance, this year’s Wimbledon, returning after the coronavirus pandemic shut down the world’s most famed tennis tournament in 2020, looks to be a diminished affair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: A Rare Look Inside a Hedge Fund Mogul’s Tax Returns
description: The multimillionaire Boaz Weinstein disclosed why he paid no or little taxes for several years.
content: Last week, ProPublica published an article about the tax records of Boaz Weinstein, the multimillionaire hedge fund manager famous for betting against the JPMorgan Chase trader known as the “London Whale.” The article reported that Mr. Weinstein and his wife, Tali Farhadian Weinstein, who is running for Manhattan district attorney and may inherit an investigation into Donald Trump’s New York State taxes, paid no or very little federal tax in “four of six recent years” between 2010 and 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marian Bull
title: Getting Married and Leaving a Roommate Behind
description: A Brooklyn couple find their own home, but saying goodbye to their roommate is ‘bittersweet.’
content: Even before the pandemic jacked up the claustrophobia levels in every New York apartment, Matt Foerster, 33, and Tanya Edmunds, 34, had outgrown theirs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Younger adults are less likely to get vaccinated than their elders, new C.D.C. studies say.
description: Many adults under 40 surveyed by researchers expressed distrust of the vaccines, fear of side effects or skepticism about the need for the shots.
content: Younger Americans are less likely to be vaccinated than their elders, and factors like income and education may affect vaccine hesitancy, according to two new studies by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: The Secrets of ‘Cognitive Super-Agers’
description: By studying centenarians, researchers hope to develop strategies to ward off Alzheimer’s disease and slow brain aging for all of us.
content: One of my greatest pleasures during the Covid-19 shutdowns was having the time to indulge in hourlong phone conversations with friends and family whom I could not see in person. Especially uplifting were my biweekly talks with Margaret Shryer, a twice-widowed 94-year-old Minneapolitan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Steven Spielberg’s Amblin Partners signs a deal with Netflix.
description: Few details were released, but the agreement will not take the place of Amblin’s current pact with Universal Pictures.
content: Netflix has scooped up one of the biggest proponents of the theatrical movie business: Steven Spielberg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and Daniel E. Slotnik
title: The White House outlines a plan to send 55 million vaccine doses to Latin America, Africa, Asia and elsewhere.
description: This tranche represents the bulk of 80 million doses that President Biden has pledged to send to countries by the end of June.
content: The White House outlined a plan on Monday to allocate 55 million doses of coronavirus vaccine around the world, the remainder of 80 million doses that President Biden pledged to send by the end of June to countries desperate for vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Trump Sues N.Y.C. for Ending Golf Course Contract After Capitol Riot
description: The Trump Organization, which had a 20-year contract to operate a public golf course in the Bronx, claims it was unfairly targeted.
content: The Trump Organization sued New York City on Monday, saying the city had wrongly terminated a lucrative golf course contract for political reasons after the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Columbia’s Newest Food Hall Is Open to the Public
description: The chef Franklin Becker oversees the new 5,000-square-foot space in Harlem.
content: A new food hall is settling in to the Jerome L. Greene Science Center at Columbia University’s satellite Harlem West campus. The opening will be Friday. It’s an umbrella project for the chef, Franklin Becker, who is overseeing the airy 5,000-square-foot space designed by Glen Coben with seating indoors and out. Mr. Becker has a lineup of four quick-serve restaurants: Butterfunk Biscuit for biscuit sandwiches, Shai Hummusiya with Mediterranean fare, Benny Casanova’s serving Sicilian pies, and the Botanist for salads that include fresh-cut herbs grown in the market. In the fall, Oliva, a full-service tapas restaurant, will open on an upper level.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Morning People May Be at Lower Risk of Depression Than Night Owls
description: Going to bed early and waking up early may help to provide some protection against depression, a new study suggests.
content: If you are a morning person, you may be at reduced risk for major depression, a new study suggests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: Medicaid Enrollment Surpassed 80 Million, a Record, During the Pandemic
description: The increase points to the program’s growing role not just as a safety net, but also as a foundation of U.S. health coverage.
content: Medicaid enrollment rose sharply during the pandemic, with nearly 10 million Americans joining the public health program for the poor, a government report released Monday showed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: The Inequality of the GoFundMe Economy
description: Online charity drives help some in need, but don’t expect them to fill the gaps in the social safety net.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Makiko Inoue
title: The Tokyo Olympics will allow spectators who live in Japan, but with restrictions.
description: The decision indicates a growing certainty that the Games will go ahead, despite months of concern that they could become a superspreader event.
content: Domestic spectators will be allowed to attend Olympic events in Tokyo this summer, the president of the Games announced on Monday, ending months of speculation that athletes could be deprived of a live audience in an effort to reduce the risk of coronavirus transmission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: ‘Just Epic’: Foo Fighters Bring Arena Rock Back, to the Vaccinated
description: Over the weekend, Foo Fighters played Madison Square Garden, the first full-capacity concert in a New York arena since March of 2020.
content: The house lights inside Madison Square Garden went down Sunday night, and the thousands of fans, packed like sardines in their seats, stood as if on cue. As they roared their approval, bouncing in place on the balls of their feet, the ground began to tremble. Cellphone flash lights illuminated the darkness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Jagame Thandhiram’ Review: Scheme, Slaughter, Repeat
description: A Tamil gangster gets recruited to work for a British tycoon in this bloody crime drama.
content: An intrepid gangster maneuvers between rival crime lords in the glossy drama “Jagame Thandhiram.” The movie (on Netflix) follows Suruli (Dhanush), whose merciless killing sprees earn him an invitation to serve under a wealthy British megalomaniac. Seduced by a big payday in pounds, Suruli uproots his life from Madurai to London and assures his new boss, Peter (James Cosmo), that no task is too vile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Polo G Earns His First No. 1 Album With ‘Hall of Fame’
description: The Chicago rapper and singer opened with the equivalent of 143,000 in sales, and Migos’s “Culture III” debuted at No. 2.
content: This spring, the Chicago rapper and singer Polo G had his first No. 1 single with “Rapstar,” and now he has completed his victory lap with his first No. 1 album.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: From Nobel Hero to Driver of War, Ethiopia’s Leader Faces Voters
description: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed plunged Ethiopia into a war in the Tigray region that spawned atrocities and famine. On Monday, his country goes to the polls.
content: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — As war raged in northern Ethiopia, and the region barreled toward its worst famine in decades, a senior American envoy flew to the Ethiopian capital last month in the hope of persuading Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed to pull his country out of a destructive spiral that many fear is tearing it apart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Shawn Hubler
title: George Clooney’s Next Project: A Public High School in Los Angeles
description: The actor and other stars will start a school to train teenagers for jobs in Hollywood, the latest in a series of entertainment industry donations to city schools.
content: LOS ANGELES — For the entertainment industry in Los Angeles, the phrase “giving back to the schools” has often meant a cameo appearance on career day or, perhaps more typically, a fat check made out to your own child’s elite private academy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Summer Solstice Brings a Day of the Sun Working Overtime
description: For those in the Northern Hemisphere, the astronomical beginning of summer brought more hours of daylight than during any other day of the year.
content: There are 24 hours in a day for everyone, but on the summer solstice the day is harder on some than on others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: Chinese port difficulties amid a Covid outbreak further snarl global trade.
description: The Shenzhen port’s capacity to handle containers plummeted early this month, and state-controlled media said on Monday that full recovery might require the rest of June.
content: SHANGHAI — Dozens of huge container ships have been forced to drop anchor and wait. Freight rates have surged. Stores in the United States and Europe find themselves with understocked shelves, higher prices or both.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Two Gods’ and ‘Conan’
description: PBS airs a documentary about a New Jersey coffin maker and his mentees. And the final episode of “Conan” airs on TBS.
content: INDEPENDENT LENS: TWO GODS (2021) 10 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). Hanif, a coffin maker in Newark takes a pair of mentees under his wing in this admirable documentary from the filmmaker Zeshawn Ali. Through intimate black-and-white footage, the film delves into Hanif’s life, and the way that his guidance bolsters his young students. Ali does this with “a matter-of-fact compassion,” Nicolas Rapold wrote in his review for The New York Times. “He cuts efficiently without turning anyone into a case study.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Iran Bets on Religion, Repression and Revolution
description: The next Iranian president’s past tells us something about the country’s future.
content: In the summer of 1988, Iran’s supreme leader, Ruhollah Khomeini, ordered the secret executions of thousands of political prisoners. Iran then denied reports of the slaughter, calling them “nothing but propaganda” based on “forgeries.” It also ruthlessly suppressed efforts by the families of the disappeared to find out what had happened to their relatives, including the location of their burial sites.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Consuewella Africa, 67, Dies; Lost Two Daughters in MOVE Siege
description: One of the girls’ remains from a 1985 police attack are believed to have ended up in a cardboard box for use in a university forensics course, provoking outrage.
content: Consuewella Africa, whose two young daughters were among 11 victims of a police siege in West Philadelphia in 1985 that began when officers tried to arrest four members of the revolutionary group MOVE and ended after the police dropped a bomb on its fortified commune, died on Wednesday in Philadelphia. She was 67.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin
title: When It Comes to Big City Elections, Republicans Are in the Wilderness
description: The party’s growing irrelevance in urban and suburban areas comes at a considerable cost, sidelining conservatives in centers of innovation and economic might.
content: When Jerry Sanders finished his second term as mayor of San Diego in 2012, he was the most prominent Republican city executive in the country. A former police chief close to the business community, Mr. Sanders appeared to be a political role model for other would-be Republican mayors, a moderate who worked with the Obama administration on urban policy and endorsed gay marriage at a pivotal moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Kenji López-Alt
title: The Understated Splendor of Grilled Oysters
description: J. Kenji López-Alt makes a compelling case for throwing your oysters on the grill this summer, and offers three vibrant ways to finish them.
content: My love of raw oysters began in 1988, when an 8-year-old me spent a warm summer evening on Cape Cod tipping back raw oysters with my dad on the back porch of a family friend’s house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: The Pandemic Stimulus Was Front-Loaded. That Could Mean a Bumpy Year.
description: There’s a risk that the affluent, who saved money by limiting things like traveling and dining out, will sit on their cash rather than spend it.
content: The U.S. economy is about to face a new challenge that has its roots in the arithmetic of growth: That which fiscal stimulus giveth, fiscal stimulus taketh away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Bengal
title: Lucy Dacus Takes Confessional Songwriting to a New Level
description: For her third solo album, “Home Video,” the singer used her childhood journals as source material.
content: In November of 2018, while on tour with the group boygenius, the singer-songwriter Lucy Dacus began performing a recently written song, “Thumbs,” partly at the urging of Phoebe Bridgers and Julien Baker, her bandmates in that project. Dacus had already drawn on her own life for the wry and charged songs on her first two solo albums, “No Burden” (2016) and “Historian” (2018), but “Thumbs” — a confessional song about a violent impulse felt toward a close friend’s abusive father — with its blunt reminder that a survivor owes an oppressor exactly nothing, resonated particularly deeply with her fans. “I’ve probably received more messages about that song than anything else I’ve written,” Dacus told me recently. On her solo tour in 2019, she occasionally closed her sets with “Thumbs,” prefacing each performance with a request that no one record it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein, Jonah E. Bromwich and Katie Glueck
title: Who Are the Billionaires’ Picks for New York Mayor? Follow the Money.
description: Ultrawealthy donors have given $16 million to super PACs dedicated to the New York City mayor’s race. Half of that money has gone to three moderate candidates.
content: More than seven years after one of the nation’s wealthiest men stepped down as New York City’s mayor and was replaced by a successor who shunned the rich, billionaires have re-emerged as a potent force in the mayor’s race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Google Executives See Cracks in Their Company’s Success
description: Despite record profits, a number of them are worried that the company is suffering from both its size and leadership from its C.E.O., Sundar Pichai.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — The seeds of a company’s downfall, it is often said in the business world, are sown when everything is going great.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.2 Million Homes in California
description: A Spanish-style house in Altadena, a two-bedroom loft in San Francisco and a contemporary home in Fairfax.
content: This house is in La Vina Estates, a gated community at the base of the San Gabriel Mountains. Most of the homes there were built in the late 1990s and early 2000s, in Spanish Revival style; many, including this one, have been updated within the last five years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Ruling Dings N.C.A.A., but It Keeps Rule-Making Power
description: The narrow ruling was not quite the blow that the critics of college sports had hoped would bring the system crashing down.
content: The N.C.A.A.’s tombstone had long ago been prepared. The marble had been polished. The cause of death — consumption — had been engraved. All that had been missing was the expiration date.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak and Alan Blinder
title: Supreme Court Backs Payments to Student-Athletes in N.C.A.A. Case
description: The association argued that the payments were a threat to amateurism and that barring them did not violate the antitrust laws.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court unanimously ruled on Monday that the N.C.A.A. could not bar relatively modest payments to student-athletes, a decision that underscored the growing challenges to a college sports system that generates huge sums for schools but provides little or no compensation to the players.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Scenes From the Final Day of Early Voting
description: The candidates make their last pitches, with Andrew Yang and Kathryn Garcia appearing together and Eric Adams denouncing gun violence.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Drucker
title: Let Yourself Enjoy This Miracle Summer
description: Rarely does the news stop to focus on the good, because there’s always another looming crisis that demands our attention.
content: When did it first hit you that, wow, things are sort of getting — better?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Petri
title: Five highlights from the final weekend of campaigning.
description: Sunday was the last day of early voting before Tuesday’s primary, and the leading Democratic candidates braved the heat to shake hands, dance and even hula hoop with supporters. Here are highlights from the final weekend.
content: Sunday was the last day of early voting before Tuesday’s primary, and the leading Democratic candidates braved the heat to shake hands, dance and even hula hoop with supporters. Here are highlights from the final weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Only the Women Can Save Us Now, New York
description: Both men leading the Democratic mayoral primary are disasters.
content: Last week I wrote about why I thought Eric Adams is very marginally preferable to Andrew Yang in New York City’s Democratic mayoral primary. Yang is likable, and I can see why people have gravitated to his sunny vision of a vibrant, business-friendly city. But electing a totally inexperienced mayor buoyed by hedge fund billionaires and singularly focused on public order seems potentially calamitous. Not because public order isn’t important — everyone wants a safe city — but because it has to be balanced with a commitment to justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward
title: Why Do Some Catholic Bishops Want to Deny Joe Biden Communion?
description: Here is what is at the root of efforts by conservative U.S. bishops to prohibit the country’s second Catholic president from receiving communion.
content: The nation’s Roman Catholic bishops last week advanced a conservative push to deny communion to President Biden, the nation’s second Catholic president, who regularly attends Mass and has spent a lifetime steeped in Christian rituals and practices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Week Inflation Panic Died
description: Don't worry: Lumber is falling and the Fed is on the case.
content: Remember when everyone was panicking about inflation, warning ominously about 1970s-type stagflation? OK, many people are still saying such things, some because that’s what they always say, some because that’s what they say when there’s a Democratic president, some because they’re extrapolating from the big price increases that took place in the first five months of this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Rancor Between Adams and Yang Marks End of Bruising Mayoral Campaign
description: On the eve of Tuesday’s primary, the top candidates for mayor of New York City issued their sharpest criticism of the campaign.
content: On the final full day of New York City’s mayoral primary campaign, the leading Democratic candidate, Eric Adams, called a top rival a “liar” and a “fraud.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A New Helper in the Kitchen
description: Red Boat’s Kho sauce adds nuance to all kinds of braised dishes, from pot roasts to tofu.
content: Cuong Pham, who, with the chef Diep Tran, created the excellent Red Boat brand fish sauce in 2011, has introduced several other products since then. The latest is Kho sauce, a kitchen shortcut made with Red Boat fish sauce, to use for braising meats and tofu. In Vietnamese kho means to simmer or braise, yielding rich satisfaction. In addition to fish sauce, it also depends on black and crushed red pepper, shallots, ginger and green onions. Keep it on hand to add substance and nuance to all kinds of braised dishes and preparations, like pot roast and the pan juices from roast chicken.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: How Big Tech Allows the Racial Wealth Gap to Persist
description: Tech companies talk a big game about racial equity. But inside their offices it’s a different story.
content: Since President Biden signed a law last week making Juneteenth a federal holiday, there has been no shortage of corporate displays of good will. Google devoted its famous “doodle” to the holiday, and many companies have declared that they will observe Juneteenth as a paid holiday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller, Conor Dougherty and Giulia Heyward
title: California Has a Plan to Pay the Back Rent for Low-Income Tenants. All of It.
description: The state is poised to embark on an ambitious, complex effort to cover the unpaid rent of low-income renters who struggled during the pandemic.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Swimming in cash from an unexpected budget surplus and federal stimulus money, California is planning rent forgiveness on a scale never seen before in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: For the Butterflies — and the Rest of Us
description: Stop using pesticides, in your butterfly garden and everywhere else.
content: NASHVILLE — For Christmas last year, my husband ordered a sign for my butterfly garden from the Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation, a nonprofit that works to protect insects and other invertebrates around the world. “Pollinator Habitat,” the sign reads. “This area has been planted with pollinator-friendly flowers and is protected from pesticides to provide valuable habitat for bees and other pollinators.” A note about where to find out more information includes a QR code that takes a smartphone straight to the Xerces Society’s “Bring Back the Pollinators” initiative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: What to Know About California’s Digital Vaccine Cards
description: Monday: State officials have said the card is not a vaccine passport. So what is it?
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Parul Sehgal
title: Yes, No, Maybe So: A Generation of Thinkers Grapples With Notions of Consent
description: Recent novels, philosophical inquiries, young adult and romance fiction, films and television shows join a robust academic literature to explore the term and its limits.
content: Love, sex, money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Joe Biden Is as Puzzled by the Senate as You Are
description: And he was a senator for 36 years.
content: Gail Collins: Bret, it’s been a while between conversations and although I’ve been on vacation I have noticed a lot of … stuff. Particularly the frozen Senate. Tell me, who’s your hero? Action-stopping Joe Manchin? Perpetually plotting Mitch McConnell? Let’s-all-get-along Mitt Romney?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Crouse
title: U.S. Swim Team Will Take 11 Teenagers to Tokyo Olympics
description: The roster reflected a generational shift as the U.S. adjusted to life after Michael Phelps.
content: OMAHA — But for the pandemic, the teenager Lydia Jacoby was a lock to go to the 2020 Olympics — as a fan on a family vacation with her parents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Chef Looks Back on the Locavore Life
description: Peter Hoffman, whose Savoy restaurant in SoHo in Manhattan was an early farm-to-table proponent, recounts the story in “What’s Good?”
content: Has it really been 10 years since Peter Hoffman closed Savoy, his steadfastly locavore gem on the edge of SoHo? Seems like yesterday. His new book, “What’s Good?,” is a lively memoir covering the arc of the restaurant’s life span, with plenty of detours into his suburban childhood; his culinary awakening; his wife and family; his interest in botany, plant genetics, biology and history; and the evolution of New York’s restaurant world. He has reason to be proud of his farm-to-table approach early in the game that depended on the nearby Union Square Greenmarket. Each chapter features a different ingredient (14 of them total), which became highlights in the restaurant, with an appropriate recipe or two for each. Leeks figure prominently. The restaurant opened in 1990 and closed in 2011, a victim of economics and the changes in SoHo, and was always a work in progress, like Mr. Hoffman’s own career. Back Forty and Back Forty West, his other places, had briefer runs. Mr. Hoffman says that he has no plans to open another New York restaurant. But another book? That’s possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Fight Over a Gentle Stream Distills Israel’s Political Divide
description: Who gets to enjoy the Asi, an exquisite squiggle of water? The question has come to symbolize the identity politics that divide Israeli society.
content: KIBBUTZ NIR DAVID, Israel — A whimsical chain of inflatable rafts tethered together by a flimsy rope floated along the Asi, a gentle stream that runs for a mile through a sunbaked plain in northern Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Errol Louis
title: He’s a Former Officer. She’s ‘Had Enough’ of the Police. Who Will Come Out Ahead?
description: In Tuesday's primary for mayor of New York City, Democrats have a choice between two distinctly different paths on policing, crime and civil rights.
content: An urgent debate is playing out right now in the Democratic Party about policing as cities see sharp rises in violent crime. The fight to control that disorder is also a battle for the direction of the party — do police departments need more resources to fight crime? Do they need to be restrained, given a long record of abuses and policies like stop-and-frisk? How do the police earn more trust from Black and brown residents? Which tactics are right, and which tactics violate our rights?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Allyson Felix qualifies for her fifth Olympic Games.
description: Allyson Felix will take aim at becoming the most decorated track and field athlete in Olympic history.
content: Allyson Felix has qualified for her fifth Olympic Games, where she will take aim at becoming the most decorated track and field athlete in Olympic history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Garcia makes closing arguments to voters, some receptive, some skeptical.
description: Kathryn Garcia spent Monday morning shaking hands and talking to voters in Manhattan and Queens, hoping that her central campaign message — that she is an experienced manager who can execute — would draw enough votes to propel her to victory.
content: Kathryn Garcia spent Monday morning shaking hands and talking to voters in Manhattan and Queens, hoping that her central campaign message — that she is an experienced manager who can execute — would draw enough votes to propel her to victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Kolaches Come to Greenwich Village
description: Brooklyn Kolache, which makes the Texas treats, has opened a branch of its Bedford-Stuyvesant shop on Bleecker Street.
content: Kolaches, the Texas specialty with Czech roots, found a home at a shop in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, nine years ago. Now an owner of Brooklyn Kolache — Autumn Stanford, a native Texan — has opened a Manhattan branch for the filled pastries, which became popular in Central Texas in the 1880s with a wave of Eastern European immigrants, mainly from Czechoslovakia. Purists will insist that the yeast-raised buns be filled only with sweetened fruit or cheese, but in Texas, savory versions with sausage, eggs, chiles and the like are wildly popular. At the new Greenwich Village store, where everything is made from scratch, sausage from nearby Faicco’s is used in the Bleecker Kolache. A new item, the Pride Roll, with cinnamon and rainbow sprinkles, is sold this month with the profits donated to the Ali Forney Center to help homeless L.G.B.T.Q. youth. There is limited outdoor seating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: An undecided voter responds to Garcia-Yang alliance: ‘Good for them.’
description: Adele Mayers was getting on the subway in Queens on Monday and on her way to work when she met one of the mayoral candidates she was considering ranking first on her ballot: Kathryn Garcia.
content: Adele Mayers was getting on the subway in Queens on Monday and on her way to work when she met one of the mayoral candidates she was considering ranking first on her ballot: Kathryn Garcia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Gives Goldman Sachs a Do-Over in Securities Fraud Suit
description: The justices said the bank may renew its arguments that its statements about honesty and integrity were too generic to support a class action for billions of dollars.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday gave Goldman Sachs another chance to try to persuade an appeals court that it should not be liable to investors who said they had lost as much as $13 billion as a consequence of what they called false statements about the investment bank’s sales of complex debt instruments before the 2008 financial crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper, Andrew Keh, Tariq Panja and Motoko Rich
title: Why Are the Olympics Still Happening? These Numbers Explain It.
description: Wondering why the Tokyo Games haven’t been canceled? The answer lies in billions of dollars, years of work and thousands of athletes who can’t wait any longer.
content: The Olympic Games have always been about numbers. After all, a motto of Citius, Altius, Fortius — faster, higher, stronger — doesn’t mean much without seconds, meters and pounds. How fast? How high? How strong?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Light Lemon Cake for Summer
description: The poundcake, from the chef Benjamin Vaschetti, is available nationwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Wiley and Garcia defend election process amid first citywide use of ranked-choice voting.
description: Maya Wiley called her rival Eric Adams’s bid to undermine confidence in ranked-choice voting “cynical, self-interested and dangerous.”
content: Two leading Democrats running for mayor moved on Monday to pre-emptively defend the results of Tuesday’s ranked-choice election, a day after allies of Eric Adams, another top candidate, suggested without evidence that an alliance between Kathryn Garcia and Andrew Yang amounted to voter suppression — and as Mr. Adams himself continued to criticize the alignment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Here Are the Democrats Running for Manhattan D.A.
description: Eight candidates are vying to take over the country’s largest local prosecutor’s office. The winner will inherit a potential Trump investigation.
content: Eight Democrats are running to replace Cyrus Vance Jr. as Manhattan district attorney, jockeying to lead one of the most well-known and influential local prosecutor’s offices in the country at a time when views of the criminal justice system have shifted.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Crucial Voting Rights Decision
description: Is the Supreme Court willing to step in and settle the fight over restrictive voter laws?
content: How does the 1965 Voting Rights Act work?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Mets Try to Improve Workplace Culture With New Guidelines
description: In a letter announcing the completion of an investigation and the departure of two longtime employees, Steven Cohen set goals for the team’s community and culture.
content: The Mets, who were rocked by a series of sexual harassment charges that resulted in the firings of two staff members this year, informed employees in a letter this week that the team would adopt new guidelines to address a workplace culture that some said fostered sexist and bullying behavior.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Black
title: Grocery-to-Table Is a Challenge for Restaurants in the Pandemic
description: Looking for new ways to get their food to customers, chefs are reinventing their dishes as retail offerings — and it can be tricky.
content: By last summer, Nick Wiseman, a founder of Little Sesame, a small chain of hummus shops in Washington, D.C., had made all the expected “pivots” to save his business. He’d offered delivery, meal kits and pantry items, and worked with local nonprofits to feed the hungry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Early voting, a first for a New York mayoral primary, drew 191,000 voters.
description: Experts described the turnout figures as strong, if not amazing. “It was slow and steady,” one strategist said.
content: This is the first time New Yorkers have been able to vote early in a mayoral primary, and experts said the turnout was pretty good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: Mark Peel, Who Helped Forge a New Culinary Path, Dies at 66
description: A pillar of California’s pioneering food scene, he worked at Spago and was a founder of the renowned Campanile and La Brea Bakery.
content: Mark Peel, one of a handful of young, educated California cooks enamored with local ingredients who emerged in the 1970s and 1980s and created a looser, farm-focused style of cuisine that would change the trajectory of American food culture, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 66.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: You’ll Want These June Bugs to Pay a Visit
description: A Pennsylvania chocolatier has updated his line of life-size chocolate scarabs, filled with flavors like lemon-mint and black cherry-vanilla.
content: Unlike cicadas, June bugs are an annual nuisance. A type of iridescent beetle, also known as a scarab, June bugs are big, noisy and harmless to people (but not to plants). Christopher Curtin, the master chocolatier who owns Éclat Chocolate in West Chester, Pa., makes his chocolate June bugs seasonally. This year he’s fine-tuned the design and given them new colors and fillings, making them as beautiful as the gilded ones that delighted the Pharoahs. They’re significant treats, more than two inches long (June bugs can actually get that big), and now come with centers of creamy apple-smoked cinnamon, black cherry-vanilla, and lemon-mint, each with a layer of pâte de fruits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed’s Williams emphasizes flexibility in the central bank’s inflation goal.
description: The New York Fed president panned Wall Street’s efforts to put an equation on the Fed’s average inflation approach.
content: John C. Williams, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said on Monday that he expects the recent acceleration in price gains to prove temporary, and offered an optimistic view of the nation’s economic outlook as widespread vaccines and business reopenings drive growth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: Many Parts of the U.S. Needed Persuading to Get Vaccinated. Not South Texas.
description: In the Rio Grande Valley, it is people’s exposure to death and disease, not offers of free beer or million-dollar prizes, that is driving vaccine rates higher.
content: BROWNSVILLE, Texas — Gabby Garcia did not expect to feel like crying when she sat down for her first dose of the coronavirus vaccine. But as the long needle pierced her skin, she thought back to the agonizing outbreak in her family that killed her sister, hospitalized her brother and also left her ill for days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: Medicaid enrollment jumped during the pandemic, a new report says.
description: Nearly 10 million Americans joined the public health coverage program for the poor through January, demonstrating the program’s increasingly important role not just as a safety net.
content: Medicaid enrollment rose sharply during the coronavirus pandemic, with nearly 10 million Americans joining the public health coverage program for the poor through January, a government report released Monday shows.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: June 21, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 21, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Raiders’ Carl Nassib Announces He’s Gay, an N.F.L. First
description: The Raiders defensive lineman came out in a statement posted to his Instagram account on Monday, becoming the first active player in the league to publicly identify as gay.
content: On Monday, Raiders defensive lineman Carl Nassib became the first active N.F.L. player to publicly declare that he is gay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Infrastructure talks collide with Democrats’ goal to tax the rich.
description: Many Democrats see the push for an infrastructure package as an opportunity to raise taxes on rich individuals and corporations. But resistance is coming from multiple directions.
content: In most years, the notion that Congress could pass a $1.2 trillion plan to fix the nation’s bridges, highways, tunnels and rail lines without raising taxes would be a politician’s dream, a vision of endless ribbon-cuttings with no angry cries of “tax and spend.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maira Garcia, Sandra E. Garcia, Isabelia Herrera, Concepción de León, Maya Phillips and A.O. Scott
title: ‘In the Heights’ and Colorism: What Is Lost When Afro-Latinos Are Erased
description: The film, set in a New York neighborhood known as the Little Dominican Republic, didn’t cast dark-skinned Latinos in lead roles. Our writers discuss how that absence reverberates.
content: “In the Heights,” the long-delayed Hollywood adaptation of the Broadway musical, has been heralded as a step for more Latino representation in Hollywood, but a conversation has emerged about colorism and the casting of the film.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Airline ticket sales dipped in May, but the industry remains optimistic.
description: Americans spent 4 percent less on flights in May than in April, and 20 percent less than May 2019.
content: Airline ticket sales fell a little in May after rising steadily in the first four months of the year, according to a firm that tracks bookings, suggesting that demand for tickets for summer travel might not be quite as strong as airlines had hoped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Who has qualified for Team U.S.A.?
description: It’s only the third of ten days at the Olympic trials, but a number of finals have already been contested.
content: It’s only the third of ten days at the Olympic trials, but a number of finals have already been contested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Populist Leaders in Eastern Europe Run Into a Little Problem: Unpopularity
description: The leaders of Slovenia, Hungary and Poland, who rode to power on waves of anti-elitism anger, face rising opposition over their pandemic responses and heavy-handed policies.
content: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia — A right-wing populist wave in Eastern Europe, lifted by Donald J. Trump’s surprise victory in 2016, has not crashed as a result of his defeat last November. But it has collided with a serious obstacle: Its leaders are not very popular.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Anthony Fauci on the Lab Leak Theory and Emailing Mark Zuckerberg
description: America’s chief immunologist claps back.
content: Anthony Fauci doesn’t have a Twitter account. But he does have a lot to say about the recent scrutiny following the release of his emails from 2020 — an especially busy time in his tenure as America’s chief immunologist. Republicans like Ron DeSantis have used the emails as fodder for criticism, accusing him of “faucism” (yes, that’s a play on fascism). Fauci’s response: “Here’s a guy whose entire life has been devoted to saving lives. And now you’re telling me he’s like Hitler? Come on, folks. Get real.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky and Vjosa Isai
title: Canada eases its hotel-quarantine rule for vaccinated citizens flying in from abroad.
description: Requiring arriving travelers to stay at a government-approved hotel, often at a high cost, has been criticized as unduly burdensome.
content: Canadian citizens and permanent residents who are fully vaccinated will be able to forgo a 14-day quarantine when arriving in the country, the Canadian government announced Monday. The new policy spares them from a polarizing requirement that they stay in a government-approved quarantine hotel.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Watch: The candidates’ plans for N.Y.C.’s recovery.
description: Supporting devastated small businesses and small landlords. Bringing back 66 million tourists and the 300,000 jobs that vanished with them. Reinvesting in neighborhoods hit hardest by Covid-19. New York City faces an enormous effort to rebuild. Here are some of the candidates’ plans for how they’ll get the job done.
content: Supporting devastated small businesses and small landlords. Bringing back 66 million tourists and the 300,000 jobs that vanished with them. Reinvesting in neighborhoods hit hardest by Covid-19. New York City faces an enormous effort to rebuild. Here are some of the candidates’ plans for how they’ll get the job done.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tsedale Lemma
title: He Promised Peace. Then He Tore His Country Apart.
description: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed is preparing to govern an Ethiopia neither respected nor whole.
content: Ahead of Ethiopia’s general election on Monday, Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed has been laying out his grand ambitions for the country. He wants it to be “comfortable for all Ethiopians,” he recently told a TV interviewer, “where every Ethiopian moves around relaxed, works and prospers.” The country, he said, should be one whose “sovereignty is respected and feared, and whose territorial integrity is preserved.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: U.S. is preparing more sanctions against Russia, the national security adviser says.
description: President Biden’s national security adviser said on Sunday, days after Mr. Biden attended his first face-to-face summit meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin, that the United States was preparing more sanctions against Russia in response to the poisoning of Aleksei A. Navalny, the country’s most prominent opposition leader.
content: President Biden’s national security adviser said on Sunday, days after Mr. Biden attended his first face-to-face summit meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin, that the United States was preparing more sanctions against Russia in response to the poisoning of Aleksei A. Navalny, the country’s most prominent opposition leader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Leibovich
title: Liz Cheney, once Republican royalty, is now a lone warrior.
description: CASPER, Wyo. — Representative Liz Cheney was holed up in a secure undisclosed location of the Dick Cheney Federal Building, recounting how she got an alarmed phone call from her father on Jan. 6.
content: CASPER, Wyo. — Representative Liz Cheney was holed up in a secure undisclosed location of the Dick Cheney Federal Building, recounting how she got an alarmed phone call from her father on Jan. 6.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Robert Quackenbush, Creator of Animal Detective Stories, Dies at 91
description: His many characters included Detective Mole, Sherlock Chick and Miss Mallard, a crime-solving duck who got her own television series.
content: Robert Quackenbush, a prolific children’s book author who conceived of the beloved character Henry the Duck, as well as detective animals like Detective Mole and Miss Mallard, died on May 17 at his home in Manhattan. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Tucker Carlson Calls Journalists ‘Animals.’ He’s Also Their Best Source.
description: His platform on Fox News made him a big player in Donald Trump’s circle. Off camera, he shapes the coverage of Trump’s world and Fox’s own internal politics.
content: Last month, I texted Tucker Carlson to ask him a question that was on my mind: “Did you get vaccinated?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: The pandemic stimulus in the U.S. was front-loaded. That could mean a bumpy year.
description: The $1.9 trillion American Rescue Plan enacted in March, as well as a $900 billion pandemic aid package passed in December, are heavily front-loaded. They were set up to get money out the door fast.
content: The $1.9 trillion American Rescue Plan enacted in March, as well as a $900 billion pandemic aid package passed in December, are heavily front-loaded. They were set up to get money out the door fast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Petri
title: Five takeaways from the final Sunday of campaigning in New York City.
description: The leading Democratic candidates for mayor braved broiling heat as they visited churches, parks and barbecues in a last push before Tuesday’s primary.
content: On the last day of early voting before Tuesday’s primary in New York City, the eight leading Democratic candidates sprinted across the boroughs on Sunday, stopping at the usual rally points like churches, parks and barbecues, as they tried to lure more voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: In 11 U.S. states, the rate of vaccination in those over 65 lags the national level.
description: One in five in that age group, mostly in the South, haven’t received a single dose, increasing the risk of virus outbreaks there.
content: There are 11 states in the United States where at least 20 percent of older adults still haven’t received a Covid shot, potentially putting the recovery there at risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi, Isabella Kwai and Ben Hubbard
title: Iran’s Incoming President Vows Tough Line on Missiles and Militias
description: Ebrahim Raisi, Iran’s ultraconservative president-elect, said that he would not meet with President Biden, and that Tehran’s position on its ballistic missile program was “nonnegotiable.”
content: Iran’s newly chosen president, in his first news conference, on Monday rejected the United States’ push for a broader deal with the Islamic Republic that would restrict its ballistic missiles program and curb its regional military policies in addition to containing its nuclear program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corinne Purtill
title: Being ‘Always On’ Has Reached Its Limits. For Parents, It’s Time to Reset.
description: What crisis-acquired habits should working parents break? Daisy Dowling author of “Workparent” weighs in.
content: — Daisy Dowling, the author of “Workparent”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Will You Get the Child Tax Credit?
description: If you’re the parent of children under 17, you may start receiving monthly cash payments.
content: If you’re the parent of children under 17, you may start receiving monthly cash payments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Hughes and Reyna Desai
title: Here’s How to Fill Out Your Ballot on Tuesday
description: New York City's primary is next week and the election will likely decide the city's next mayor.
content: New York City's primary is next week and the election will likely decide the city's next mayor.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $2.2 Million in California
description: A Spanish-style house in Altadena, a two-bedroom loft in San Francisco and a contemporary home in Fairfax.
content: A Spanish-style house in Altadena, a two-bedroom loft in San Francisco and a contemporary home in Fairfax.

author: By The New York Times
title: White House Outlines Plan to Send 55 Million Vaccine Doses Globally
description: Officials on Monday announced a global allocation plan for 55 million coronavirus vaccine doses, the remainder of 80 million doses that President Biden pledged to send overseas to countries in need by the end of June.
content: Officials on Monday announced a global allocation plan for 55 million coronavirus vaccine doses, the remainder of 80 million doses that President Biden pledged to send overseas to countries in need by the end of June.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Investing in the Future of Sustainability
description: Learn how Fidelity portfolio manager Nicole Connolly approaches sustainable investing.

author: By The New York Times
title: Carl Nassib Becomes First Openly Gay Active N.F.L. Player
description: The Raiders defensive lineman came out in a video posted on social media and said he would donate $100,000 to the Trevor Project, a nonprofit dedicated to suicide prevention efforts for L.G.B.T.Q. youth.
content: The Raiders defensive lineman came out in a video posted on social media and said he would donate $100,000 to the Trevor Project, a nonprofit dedicated to suicide prevention efforts for L.G.B.T.Q. youth.

title: Do You Have a Love Story About Being Separated by National Borders?
description: The Modern Love podcast wants to hear from you.
content: As the saying goes, “Love knows no bounds.” However, national borders can often hold back lovers and families from being together.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Readers decry the possibility that the church will refuse communion for the president. Also: The health care ruling; Joe Manchin; unvaccinated hospital workers; roadkill; dress for a funeral.
